cards.back: Output depends only on present and past inputs, not future inputs. Can be implemented in real-time. h(t) = 0 for t < 0.
Output at time t depends only on input at time t. No memory of past values. Examples: resistor (v=iR), ideal amplifier (y=Kx).
If x(t)→y(t), then x(t-T)→y(t-T) for any T. The system behavior doesn't change over time. Same input at different times gives same output, just shifted.

Superposition holds: ax₁+bx₂ → ay₁+by₂
Combines additivity (x₁+x₂→y₁+y₂) and homogeneity (ax→ay).
Bounded-Input Bounded-Output: |x(t)| < M implies |y(t)| < N for some finite M, N. System won't 'blow up' for reasonable inputs.
No! Output depends on future input x(t+2). Cannot be implemented in real-time. This is a non-causal (or acausal) system.
No! Violates homogeneity: if input is 2x, output is 4x², not 2x². Squaring is a nonlinear operation.
No! The multiplication by t makes the system behavior change over time. Same input at different times gives different outputs.
Linear Time-Invariant system. Satisfies both linearity (superposition) and time-invariance. Can be fully characterized by impulse response h(t). Analyzed using convolution.
Causal (if T≥0), linear, time-invariant. A perfect LTI system. Delay lines are fundamental building blocks of signal processing.
